qc.notes: The image set is sufficient for analysis. Note that dedicated close-up views for the left cheek and left under-eye were not provided; analysis for these regions relies on the 45-degree and frontal views.

skin_type.label: combination
skin_type.rationale: The analysis reveals a pattern of increased gloss and pore prominence on the T-zone (forehead, nose), indicative of higher sebum production, while the cheek areas appear more balanced and less shiny. This differential in oil distribution is the classic presentation of combination skin.

skin_tone_fitzpatrick.label: IV
skin_tone_fitzpatrick.note: This is a visual estimation. Skin with this tone has substantial melanin, typically tans easily, and has a low propensity for sunburn.

skin_age_range.rationale: This estimate is based on the presence of superficial fine lines, particularly in the periorbital region, and mild signs of photoaging such as some textural unevenness and pigmentation, consistent with the user-provided age of 39.

analysis.overview_explanation: Your skin appears healthy overall, with the most noticeable concerns being related to the delicate under-eye area and some unevenness in skin tone and texture. The analysis indicates some dark circles and fine lines under the eyes, along with scattered spots of hyperpigmentation on the cheeks. Managing these areas, along with balancing oil in the T-zone, will be key to achieving your skin goals.

pores.rationale_plain: Your pores are most prominent in the T-zone, particularly on and around your nose and extending to the inner cheeks. They appear as small to medium-sized openings. On your forehead and chin, they are less noticeable.
possible_causes: Pore size is largely determined by genetic factors.
Increased sebum production, especially in the T-zone, can make pores appear more prominent.
A gradual loss of skin elasticity associated with aging can affect the appearance of pores.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The visibility of your pores is clearly concentrated on your nose, the central part of your forehead, and inner cheeks, which aligns with the classic T-zone distribution.
likely_causes: This pattern is due to a higher density of sebaceous glands in the T-zone compared to other areas of the face.
Genetic factors play a significant role in determining where pores are most visible.
Sebum and debris can collect in these pores, making them appear more conspicuous.
care_education: Thoroughly cleansing the skin, especially in the T-zone, can help remove excess oil and debris that can stretch pores.
Products containing ingredients that help regulate sebum and promote cell turnover can minimize their appearance.
While you cannot change the genetic size of your pores, keeping them clear can make them look smaller.

wrinkles.rationale_plain: The analysis shows mainly superficial, fine lines. These are most apparent in the delicate under-eye area. There are also very faint, early horizontal lines on the forehead, but no deep, set-in wrinkles or folds are visible.
possible_causes: Fine lines are a natural result of the intrinsic aging process and decreasing collagen levels.
Cumulative sun exposure is a primary factor that accelerates the formation of wrinkles.
Repetitive facial expressions, such as smiling or squinting, contribute to lines around the eyes and on the forehead.

identified_subtypes.explanation: These are very fine, shallow lines visible on the skin's surface, particularly noticeable under the eyes where the skin is thinnest.
likely_causes: The primary cause is a decrease in collagen and elastin due to both intrinsic aging and sun damage.
Dehydration can make these fine lines appear more prominent.
Repetitive muscle movements from facial expressions etch these lines into the skin over time.
care_education: Keeping the skin well-hydrated with moisturizers can temporarily plump the skin and make fine lines less obvious.
Sunscreen is a critical tool to prevent the collagen breakdown that leads to the formation of new lines.
Using products with ingredients that support collagen production can help improve the skin's resilience over the long term.

pigmentation.rationale_plain: Your skin displays some areas of uneven tone, primarily characterized by small, scattered darker spots (macules) across your cheeks. This gives the complexion a slightly mottled appearance rather than a uniform tone. The contrast is mild to moderate but is visible across several views.
possible_causes: Chronic and cumulative sun exposure is the most common cause of acquired hyperpigmentation like sun spots.
Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation can occur after any skin inflammation, such as minor breakouts or irritation.
Hormonal fluctuations, such as those related to pregnancy or certain medications, can sometimes trigger pigmentation.

identified_subtypes.explanation: These appear as small, distinct, and slightly darkened macules, most visible on the higher points of your cheeks, which receive significant sun exposure.
likely_causes: They are a direct result of cumulative, long-term exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun.
The tendency to develop sun spots can also be influenced by genetic factors.
Lighter or more frequent sun exposure without adequate protection can accelerate their formation.
care_education: The most effective management is prevention through the daily and consistent use of a high-SPF, broad-spectrum sunscreen.
Ingredients known to help with skin brightening and cell turnover can be incorporated into a skincare routine to improve the appearance of existing spots.
Protecting your skin with hats and seeking shade during peak sun hours provides additional defense against UV damage.

citations.title: Skin Pigmentation Types, Causes and Treatmentâ€”A Review (PMC)

redness.rationale_plain: Your skin shows very little signs of redness. There is a trace amount of redness localized to the creases around your nostrils (alar folds), which is very common and typically not a significant concern. The rest of your face appears to have a calm and even tone.
possible_causes: This is a common area for minor irritation due to friction from cleansing or blowing one's nose.
The creases can sometimes become dry, leading to mild inflammation and redness.
Some individuals naturally have more visible capillaries in this specific area.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The redness is not widespread but is confined to a very specific, small area around the base of the nose.
likely_causes: This area is prone to irritation and dryness, which can cause mild, localized redness.
Allergies or colds can lead to friction from tissues, contributing to this appearance.
It is a common area for sensitivity for many individuals.
care_education: Be gentle when cleansing or touching this area to avoid further irritation.
Applying a simple, soothing moisturizer can help to protect the skin barrier.
If the redness becomes persistent, painful, or spreads, consulting a doctor is recommended.

texture.rationale_plain: While your skin is generally smooth, there is a noticeable grainy quality in certain areas, particularly around the eyes where tiny, pin-point sized bumps are visible. Additionally, the visible pores on your nose and inner cheeks contribute to an uneven surface appearance.
possible_causes: A buildup of dead skin cells and sebum can lead to clogged pores and a rough or grainy feel.
The tiny bumps under the eyes may be milia, which are small cysts of trapped keratin.
Dehydration can also temporarily make skin texture appear less smooth.

identified_subtypes.explanation: Your skin surface has areas that are smooth alongside areas with more prominent pores, creating a variance in texture, especially between your T-zone and cheeks.
likely_causes: A primary cause is the variation in sebum production across different facial zones.
Sun damage over time can affect skin elasticity and contribute to larger-looking pores.
Inconsistent exfoliation can lead to a buildup of cells that roughens the skin's surface.
care_education: A consistent cleansing and moisturizing routine helps maintain the skin's barrier and overall health.
Incorporating gentle exfoliation can help to smooth the skin's surface by removing dead cell buildup.
Proper hydration is key, as well-hydrated skin often appears smoother and more plump.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The close-up images reveal very small, skin-colored bumps, especially on the thin skin under the eyes and on the eyelids. This contributes to a fine, grainy surface rather than a perfectly smooth one.
likely_causes: These tiny bumps are often milia, which form when keratin becomes trapped beneath the skin's surface.
They can sometimes be associated with the use of heavy creams around the eye area.
A slow rate of natural cell turnover can also contribute to their formation.
care_education: Avoid trying to extract these at home, as this can lead to scarring, especially in the delicate eye area.
Gentle chemical exfoliants may help over time, but care must be taken around the eyes.
A dermatologist or licensed esthetician can safely extract milia.

acne.rationale_plain: Your skin appears clear of any significant acne lesions. The images do not show evidence of comedones (blackheads or whiteheads), inflammatory papules, or pustules.
possible_causes: Not applicable as no significant acne was detected.
Effective skincare or a natural disposition may contribute to clear skin.
Hormonal balance can also play a role in preventing acne.

citations.title: Review of acne grading scales incl. GAGS (PMC)

under_eye.rationale_plain: The area under your eyes shows noticeable darkening compared to the surrounding cheek skin. There also appears to be a slight hollowness in the tear trough area, which creates a shadow and can contribute to the appearance of dark circles. A few very fine lines are also visible in the close-up images.
possible_causes: Under-eye pigmentation can be genetic and is common in certain skin tones.
The shadow effect is often related to facial anatomy and can become more apparent with age-related volume changes.
Fine lines can result from a combination of sun exposure and repeated facial expressions.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The brownish discoloration visible under the eyes suggests an excess of melanin in the skin, which is a common cause of dark circles.
likely_causes: Genetic predisposition is a primary factor for this type of under-eye concern.
Chronic sun exposure can stimulate melanin production and worsen pigmentation.
Inflammation from rubbing or allergies can sometimes lead to post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation.
care_education: Consistent use of a broad-spectrum sunscreen is crucial to prevent the pigmentation from darkening.
Using gentle, targeted eye creams with ingredients that can help brighten the skin may be beneficial.
Always be gentle when applying or removing products around the eye area to avoid irritation.

identified_subtypes.explanation: The natural contour of your bone structure creates a subtle indentation or 'tear trough' under the eye. This trough can cast a shadow that makes the area appear darker.
likely_causes: This is largely determined by individual facial anatomy and genetics.
The appearance can become more pronounced with natural age-related shifts in facial fat pads.
Dehydration can sometimes temporarily accentuate the appearance of hollows.
care_education: While topical products cannot change bone structure, keeping the skin well-hydrated can help improve its overall appearance.
Some cosmetic procedures performed by a dermatologist can address structural hollows, but this is a decision to be made with a medical professional.
Proper sleep and hydration can have a positive impact on the overall freshness of the eye area.

citations.title: Validated photonumeric scale for infraorbital dark circles (PMC)

under_eye.uncertainty_notes: The left under-eye area was assessed from angled and frontal views, as a dedicated close-up was not available.

limitations: This is not a medical diagnosis.
The analysis is based on a limited set of 2D images and may not capture the full condition of the skin.
Lighting conditions (glare on the T-zone) can influence visual assessment of oiliness and texture.
Missing dedicated close-up views for the left side of the face slightly reduces confidence for those specific regions.
